Alpine tundra ecosystems are controlled by a low temperature. The lower temperature with
increasing altitude accounts for more than 80% of the variation among summits to explain the
tundra zone, and indirectly change the precipitation and snow cover, which leads to changes in
species’ composition. Species with similar distributions respond similarly to large and local ecological
]. Biogeographic deconstruction has been used to assess community patterns of species
erent habitats and their ecological requirements [
]. Compared with previous analysis at the
community level in the Changbai alpine tundra, our analysis at the species level provided a better
understanding of the inﬂuence of altitude and micro-topography on the changes in the distribution
of shrub and herbaceous plants, and shift of the tundra species’ composition under climate change.
For example, six herbaceous species have already occupied lower elevations, a semi-sunny slope aspect,
steep slope, and depression in that tundra, which shifted the shrub tundra to the shrub-herb tundra.
Our results showed that the Shannon-Wiener index was mainly a
ected by the altitude, whereas the
herb ratio and six herbaceous dominant species were signiﬁcantly a
slope grade, and slope aspects. These ﬁndings are consistent with earlier studies [
3.2. Implication for Possible Causes of Changes in the Tundra Vegetation
Our results indicated that herbaceous species gradually migrated fromlower elevations to tundra
at high elevations. In the cold conditions of the tundra of the Changbai Mountains, shrubs have
]. With global warming, the growing season temperature,
and the length of the growing season, have increased and are continuously increasing in the tundra of
]. These factors allow historically low elevation species (herbs) to survive
at higher elevations. Our results are consistent with those of previous studies where air warming
resulted in herbaceous plant invasion into alpine and arctic tundras [
Our results showedthat herbs typically existedon semi-sunny slopes, steep slopes, anddepression.
It means that micro-topography and slope grade play a greater role in determining herbs invasion,
]. By the 1980s, shrubs covered almost all areas of the tundra,
except for patches covered by permanent snow on the Changbai Mountains [

ects of tundra climate change associated with air warming, increased precipitation, and
]. For instance, shortened snowfall season and reduced snow
], less snow, and thinner winter snow cover weaken the protective e
ect species’ distribution and community composition on a small

]. The six herb species belong to thermophilic
]. Therefore, we found that herbs typically occurred on semi-sunny slopes.
Studies have shown that the volcanic eruption 800 years ago in Changbai Mountain destroyed the
vegetation completely and caused a primary succession of vegetation. After the volcanic disturbance,
the process of succession could be divided into ﬁve stages: bare land, lichen-bryophyte community,
herbaceous community, shrub-herbaceous community, and shrub community [
studies have also conﬁrmed that vegetation succession stages di
